  "article_text": [
    "_ sturmian words _ are well - described objects in combinatorics on words . they can be defined in several equivalent ways @xcite , e.g.  as words coding a two - interval exchange transformation with irrational ratio of lengths of the intervals .",
    "morphisms preserving the set of sturmian words are called _ sturmian _ and they form a monoid generated by three of its elements ( see @xcite ) .",
    "let us denote this monoid by @xmath4 .    in this paper , we consider morphisms preserving the set of words coding a three - interval exchange transformation with permutation @xmath5 , the so - called _ 3iet words_. we call these morphisms _ 3iet - preserving_. monoid of these morphisms , denoted by @xmath6 , is not fully described .",
    "it is shown ( see @xcite ) that the monoid @xmath6 is not finitely generated . recently , in @xcite , pairs of amicable sturmian morphisms were defined . the authors used this notion to describe morphisms that have as a fixed point a non - degenerate 3iet word , i.e. word with complexity @xmath7 . using the operation of `` ternarization '' , we can assign a morphism @xmath8 over a ternary alphabet to a pair of amicable sturmian morphisms .",
    "we show that such @xmath2 is a 3iet - preserving morphism .",
    "moreover , we show that the set @xmath9 is a monoid , but it does not cover the whole monoid @xmath6 .",
    "we also study the incidence matrices of morphisms @xmath10 . from the definition of amicable sturmian morphisms @xmath11 we can derive that @xmath0 and @xmath1 have the same incidence matrix @xmath12 , where @xmath13 .",
    "as shown in  @xcite , for every matrix @xmath14 with @xmath13 , there exist @xmath15 sturmian morphisms .",
    "we will show the following theorem concerning the number of pairs of amicable sturmian morphisms with a given matrix .",
    "[ thm : amn ] let @xmath16 be a matrix with @xmath13 . then there exist exactly @xmath17 pairs of amicable sturmian morphisms with incidence matrix @xmath18 , where @xmath19 and @xmath20",
    "moreover , for a given matrix @xmath18 , we will describe all matrices @xmath21 such that @xmath22 is an incidence matrix of @xmath8 for amicable sturmian morphisms @xmath23 with incidence matrix @xmath18 .",
    "besides the infinite words , we consider _ finite words _ over the alphabet @xmath24 .",
    "we write @xmath25 , where @xmath26 for all @xmath27 , @xmath28 .",

    "the language of an infinite word is denoted by @xmath60 .",
    "it is known that the language of neither sturmian nor 3iet word depends on the point @xmath61 , the orbit of which the infinite word codes .",
    "it depends only on slope @xmath62 or parameters @xmath63 .",
    "the _ ( factor ) complexity _ of an infinite word @xmath55 is a mapping @xmath64 , which returns the number of factors of @xmath55 of the length @xmath30 , thus @xmath65 .",
    "it is easy to see that a word @xmath55 is periodic if and only if there exists @xmath66 such that @xmath67 .",
    "we consider sturmian words , i.e.  aperiodic words given by exchange of 2 intervals with permutation @xmath68 , and words given by exchange of 3 intervals with permutation @xmath5 .",
    "let us recall that general @xmath69-interval exchange transformations were introduced already in @xcite .",
    "the 2-interval exchange transformation @xmath70 is a mapping @xmath71 .",
    "it is determined by its slope @xmath72 $ ] and is given by @xmath73 the orbit of a point @xmath61 with respect to the transformation @xmath70 , i.e.  the sequence @xmath74 can be coded by an infinite word @xmath75 on the binary alphabet @xmath76 .",
    "the infinite word is given by @xmath77 it is a well - known fact that for an irrational @xmath62 , the word @xmath55 is sturmian .",
    "using the same construction on the partition of the interval @xmath78 $ ] into @xmath79\\cup(\\varepsilon,1]$ ] , we again obtain a sturmian word . on the other hand ,",
    "every sturmian word can be obtained by one of the above two constructions .",
    "the set of sturmian words will be denoted by @xmath80 .    in @xcite (",

    "for combinatorial properties of 3iet words , see @xcite .",

    "<S> any amicable pair @xmath0 , @xmath1 of sturmian morphisms enables a construction of a ternary morphism @xmath2 which preserves the set of infinite words coding 3-interval exchange . </S>",
